TypeSignature.Value: public sealed class OracleParameter : System.Data.Common.DbParameter, ICloneable

.class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit OracleParameter extends System.Data.Common.DbParameter implements class System.Data.IDataParameter, class System.Data.IDbDataParameter, class System.ICloneable

Docs.summary: Represents a parameter to an and optionally its mapping to a . This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Parameter names are not case-sensitive.
When querying an Oracle database using the Microsoft OLE DB Provider for Oracle (MSDAORA) and the ODBC.NET Framework Data Provider, using the `LIKE` clause to query values in fixed-length fields may not return all expected matches. The reason is that when Oracle matches values for fixed-length fields in a `LIKE` clause, it matches the entire length of the string, including any padding trailing spaces. For example, if a table in an Oracle database contains a field named "Field1" that is defined as `char(3)`, and you enter the value "a" into a row of that table, the following code will not return the row.
```vb# Dim queryString As String = "SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Field1 LIKE ?" Dim command As OleDbCommand = New OleDbCommand(queryString, connection) command.Parameters.Add("@p1", OleDbType.Char, 3).Value = "a" Dim reader As OleDbDataReader = command.ExecuteReader() ```
```c# string queryString = "SELECT * FROM Table1 WHERE Field1 LIKE ?"; OleDbCommand command = new OleDbCommand(queryString, connection); command.Parameters.Add("@p1", OleDbType.Char, 3).Value = "a"; OleDbDataReader reader = command.ExecuteReader(); ```
This is because Oracle stores the column value as "a " (padding "a", with trailing spaces, to the fixed field length of 3), which Oracle does not treat as a match for the parameter value of "a" in the case of a `LIKE` comparison of fixed-length fields.
To resolve this problem, append a percentage ("%") wildcard character to the parameter value (`"a%"`), or use an SQL `=` comparison instead.
## Examples The following example creates multiple instances of OracleParameter through the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameterCollection> within the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>. These parameters are used to select data from the database and place the data in the <xref:System.Data.DataSet>. This example assumes that a <xref:System.Data.DataSet> and an <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> have already been created by using the appropriate schema, commands, and connection.
[!code-vb[Classic WebData OracleParameter#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.data.oracleclie_2_1.vb)] [!code-cs[Classic WebData OracleParameter#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.data.oracleclie_2_1.cs)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks When you specify an <xref:System.Object> in the `value` parameter, the <xref:System.Data.DbType> is inferred from the Microsoft .NET Framework type of the <xref:System.Object>.
Use caution when you are using this overload of the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter> constructor. Because this overload takes a `value` of type <xref:System.Object>, you must convert the integral value to an <xref:System.Object> type when the value is zero, as the following Microsoft Visual C# example demonstrates.
``` Parameter = new OracleParameter("pname", Convert.ToInt32(0)); ```
If you do not perform this conversion, the compiler will assume that you are trying to call the `OracleParameter`(`string`, `OracleType`) constructor overload.

MemberSignature.Value: public override System.Data.DbType DbType { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype System.Data.DbType DbType

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the of the parameter.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A> and DbType are linked. Therefore, setting the DbType changes the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A> to a supporting <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A>.
The DbType, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A>, and <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Size%2A> properties of a parameter can be inferred by setting <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value%2A>. Therefore, you are not required to specify them. However, they are not exposed in <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter> property settings. For example, if the size of the parameter has been inferred, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Size%2A> does not contain inferred value after statement execution. For `String` data types the default is <xref:System.Data.DbType>.
For a list of the supported data types, see the appropriate <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A> member. For more information, see [DataAdapter Parameters](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

remarks.format:
## Remarks The OracleType and <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.DbType%2A> are linked. Therefore, setting the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.DbType%2A> changes the OracleType to a supporting <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleType>.
The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.DbType%2A>, OracleType, and <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Size%2A> properties of a parameter can be inferred by setting <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value%2A>. Therefore, you are not required to specify them. However, they are not exposed in <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter> property settings. For example, if the size of the parameter has been inferred, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Size%2A> does not contain inferred value after statement execution. For `String` data types the default is <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleType>.
For a list of the supported data types, see the appropriate <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleType> member. For more information, see [DataAdapter Parameters](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

remarks.format: ## Remarks Setting the Precision or <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Scale%2A> properties has no effect.

MemberSignature.Value: public override void ResetDbType ();
.method public hidebysig virtual instance void ResetDbType() cil managed

Docs.summary: Resets the type associated with this .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When executing a command that includes parameter values, code can either set the type of a parameter explicitly, or the parameter can infer its type from its value. Calling this method resets the parameter so that it can again infer its type from the value passed in the parameter. Calling this method affects both the <xref:System.Data.Odbc.OdbcParameter.DbType%2A> and <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter>.

.method public hidebysig instance void ResetOracleType() cil managed

Docs.summary: Resets the type associated with this .

remarks.format: ## Remarks When executing a command that includes parameter values, code can either set the type of a parameter explicitly, or the parameter can infer its type from its value. Calling this method resets the parameter so that it can again infer its type from the value passed in the parameter. Calling this method affects both the <xref:System.Data.Odbc.OdbcParameter.DbType%2A> and <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A> properties of the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter>.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Setting the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Precision%2A> or Scale properties has no effect.

MemberSignature.Value: public override int Size { get; set; }
.property instance int32 Size

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size, in bytes, of the data within the column.
Docs.value: The maximum size, in bytes, of the data within the column. The default value is 0 (to be used when you do not want to specify the maximum size of the value).

remarks.format:
## Remarks Setting Size affects only the input value of a parameter. Return values and output parameters are not affected by this property.
The Size property is used for binary and string types.
For nonstring data types and ANSI string data, the Size property refers to the number of bytes. For Unicode string data, Size refers to the number of characters. The count for strings does not include the terminating character.
For variable-length data types, Size describes the maximum amount of data to transmit to the server. For example, for a Unicode string value, Size could be used to limit the amount of data sent to the server to the first one hundred characters.
For bidirectional and output parameters, and return values, you must set the value of Size. This is not required for input parameters, and if not explicitly set, the value of is inferred from the actual size of the specified parameter when a parameterized statement is executed.
The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.DbType%2A>, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A>, and Size properties of a parameter can be inferred by setting <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value%2A>. Therefore, you are not required to specify them. However, they are not exposed in <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter> property settings. For example, if the size of the parameter has been inferred, Size does not contain inferred value after statement execution.
For fixed length data types, the value of Size is ignored. It can be retrieved for informational purposes, and returns the maximum amount of bytes the provider uses when transmitting the value of the parameter to the server.
## Examples The following example creates a <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter> and sets some of its properties.
```vb# Public Sub CreateOracleParameter() Dim parameter As New OracleParameter("pDescription", OracleType.VarChar) parameter.IsNullable = True parameter.Direction = ParameterDirection.Output parameter.Size = 88 End Sub ```
```c# public void CreateOracleParameter() { OracleParameter parameter = new OracleParameter("pDescription", OracleType.VarChar); parameter.IsNullable = true; parameter.Direction = ParameterDirection.Output; parameter.Size = 88; } ```

MemberSignature.Value: public override string SourceColumn { get; set; }
.property instance string SourceColumn

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the name of the source column mapped to the and used for loading or returning the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Value%2A>
Docs.value: The name of the source column mapped to the . The default is an empty string ("").

MemberSignature.Value: public override bool SourceColumnNullMapping { get; set; }
.property instance bool SourceColumnNullMapping

Docs.summary: Sets or gets a value which indicates whether the source column is nullable. This allows to correctly generate Update statements for nullable columns.
Docs.value: if the source column is nullable, otherwise .

remarks.format:
## Remarks SourceColumnNullMapping is used by the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> to correctly generate update commands when dealing with nullable columns. Generally, use of SourceColumnNullMapping is limited to developers inheriting from <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder>.
<xref:System.Data.Common.DbCommandBuilder> uses this property to determine whether the source column is nullable, and sets this property to `true` if it is nullable, and `false` if it is not. When <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> is generating its Update statement, it examines the SourceColumnNullMapping for each parameter. If the property is `true`, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> generates a WHERE clauses like the following (in this query expression, "FieldName" represents the name of the field):
``` ((@IsNull_FieldName = 1 AND FieldName IS NULL) OR (FieldName = @Original_FieldName)) ```
If SourceColumnNullMapping for the field is false, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> generates the following WHERE clause:
``` FieldName = @OriginalFieldName ```
In addition, @IsNull_FieldName contains 1 if the source field contains null, and 0 if it does not. This mechanism allows for a performance optimization in Oracle Server, and provides for common code that works across multiple providers.

MemberSignature.Value: public override object Value { get; set; }
.property instance object Value

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the value of the parameter.
Docs.value: An object that is the value of the parameter. The default value is null.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For input parameters, the value is bound to the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand> that is sent to the server. For output and return-value parameters, the value is set on completion of the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand> and after the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataReader> is closed.
For an input parameter, Value can be set to an object of either a Microsoft .NET Framework data type or an Oracle data type (for example, an <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber> or <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString>).
When you send a null parameter value to the server, you must specify DBNull, not null. A null value in the system is an empty object that has no value. DBNull is used to represent null values.
If the application specifies the database type, the bound value is converted to that type when the provider sends the data to the server. The provider tries to convert any type of value if it supports the <xref:System.IConvertible> interface. Conversion errors may result if the specified type is not compatible with the value.
The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.DbType%2A>, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.OracleType%2A>, and <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter.Size%2A> properties of a parameter can be inferred by setting Value. Therefore, you are not required to specify them. However, they are not exposed in <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameter> property settings. For example, if the size of the parameter has been inferred, Size does not contain inferred value after statement execution.
The `InputOutput`, `Output`, and `ReturnValue`<xref:System.Data.ParameterDirection> values used by the Value property will be Microsoft .NET Framework data types, unless the input value was an Oracle data type (for example, <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleNumber> or <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleString>). This does not apply to REF CURSOR, BFILE, or LOB data types.
The Value property is overwritten by the **Update** method.
